Introduction

Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a life-threatening condition caused by exotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus within a retained foreign body or a wound infection.  It is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, rash, hypotension, and multiorgan dysfunction.

Risk factors



Risk factors for the development of staphylococcal TSS include the following:



  • Retained foreign body (eg, tampon, nasal/vaginal packing); prolonged, single use increases risk
  • Surgical/postpartum wound infection
  • Skin and soft tissue infections (eg, mastitis, burns)


Wounds may not appear infected due to a poor local inflammatory response.

Pathophysiology



Staphylococcal TSS is an exotoxin-mediated disease.  Most cases are linked to prolonged tampon use, nasal wound packing, or wound infections, each of which provide a medium for localized S aureus proliferation and the elaboration of pyrogenic toxin superantigens (eg, TSS toxin-1) into the bloodstream.



These exotoxins are called superantigens because they bypass normal intracellular antigen processing (

figure 1
).  Normally, major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II) antigens are processed by the phagolysosome.  However, superantigens can bind to the invariant region of the MHC-II of antigen-presenting cells without first being internalized and processed.



The superantigen/MHC-II complex subsequently interacts with the variable part of the T-cell receptor beta chain, which results in widespread, indiscriminate stimulation of a large percentage (>20%) of total T cells and the massive release of inflammatory cytokines (eg, IL-1, IL-2, TNF-alpha and TNF-beta, interferon-gamma).  Massive cytokine release mediates the major manifestations of TSS.

Clinical presentation



Staphylococcal TSS presents with acute-onset high fever and chills with rapid progression (over <48 hours) into a multisystem disorder characterized by following:



  • Rash:  Diffuse macular rash (erythroderma) that usually involves the palms and soles.
  • Hypotension
  • Multiorgan involvement
    • Gastrointestinal:  Vomiting and diarrhea
    • Muscular:  Myalgia, weakness, and increased creatine phosphokinase
    • Renal:  Oliguria, increased blood urea nitrogen and creatinine, and metabolic derangements (eg, hyponatremia)
    • Hepatic:  Increased transaminases and bilirubin
    • Hematologic:  Thrombocytopenia (disseminated intravascular coagulation [eg, â†‘ PT and PTT])
    • Neurologic:  Confusion, dizziness, and seizure
    • Pulmonary:  Respiratory distress and bilateral crackles


Desquamation of the rash (particularly of the palms and soles) typically occurs 1-2 weeks later.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of staphylococcal TSS requires BOTH of the following:



  • Characteristic clinical features of rapid-onset fever, rash, and hypotension
  • Evidence of multiorgan dysfunction (eg, elevated creatinine, elevated transaminases, thrombocytopenia) without an alternate cause


Additional laboratory findings may include neutrophilia, although leukocyte count is often normal.



Microbiological confirmation of S aureus should be attempted via cultures from mucosal sites (eg, vagina, nares) in cases of foreign body TSS and from any infected wounds but is not required for diagnosis.  Blood cultures also should be obtained but are usually negative.



Imaging is not required for diagnosis but may identify sources of infection (eg, deep soft tissue infection).

Differential diagnosis



  • Streptococcal TSS:  can include group A Streptococcus (GAS) superantigens, leads to fever and multiorgan dysfunction similar to staphylococcal TSS; however, diffuse erythema is not a typical finding.  In addition, a distinct feature associated with streptococcal TSS is pain out of proportion to minor trauma (hyperalgesia) that usually precedes an apparent skin/soft tissue infection caused by invasive GAS.
  • Sepsis due to other pathogens:  typically includes symptoms of fever, hypotension, and multiorgan failure, but diffuse erythema with desquamation is not expected.
  • Meningococcal infection:  commonly presents with fever, vomiting, and rapid-onset shock.  The associated rash is typically petechial, and meningeal signs (eg, nuchal rigidity) are characteristic.
  • Rocky Mountain spotted fever:  develops fever and vomiting followed by rash (involving the palms and soles), hypotension, and multiorgan involvement.  Although the rash may be initially macular, it quickly evolves to petechiae.  It also characteristically begins on the extremities and spreads centripetally.
  • Kawasaki disease:  is a vasculitis in children that causes prolonged fever with conjunctivitis, mucositis, cervical lymphadenopathy, rash, and extremity changes (eg, edema/erythema).  Hemodynamic instability and multiorgan failure do not occur.
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome:  is a severe skin reaction to certain medications or infections and is characterized by a prodrome of fever and influenza-like symptoms, followed by mucocutaneous erythema and purpuric macules that progress to necrosis and sloughing of the epidermis.
  • Scarlet fever:  in children with a recent group A streptococcal infection (eg, pharyngitis) develops as a prodrome of fever, headache, and sore throat that is typically followed by fine, pink, blanching papules with flexural accentuation (rough, sandpaper-like texture).  Hypotension and organ failure do not occur.
  • Secondary syphilis:  manifestations include a maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles along with low-grade fever.  The course is indolent, and shock is not typical.

Management



Treatment of staphylococcal TSS includes the following:



  • Resuscitative treatment:  Massive cytokine release often causes intractable hypotension and diffuse capillary leak, necessitating high-volume fluid replacement and pressor therapy.
  • Source control:  Infected foreign bodies (eg, tampons, nasal packing) must be removed.  When TSS is due to a surgical or postpartum wound, wound exploration with debridement is often necessary.
  • Empiric antibiotics, including ALL of the following:
    • Vancomycin, which provides bactericidal activity against methicillin-resistant S aureus
    • Clindamycin, which inhibits the bacterial ribosome, leading to a drastic reduction in exotoxin production
    • A penicillin/beta-lactamase inhibitor (eg, piperacillin-tazobactam), cefepime, or a carbapenem for gram-negative coverage until cultures are finalized (manifestations of TSS can be similar to those of gram-negative sepsis)


Antibiotic coverage can be tailored to S aureus alone (ie, vancomycin and clindamycin) if cultures are confirmatory.

Prognosis



Mortality rate is reduced with prompt diagnosis and treatment but remains approximately 5% (eg, due to arrhythmia or respiratory failure).



Most patients recover fully, although permanent organ dysfunction (eg, renal dysfunction) can occur.

Summary



Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (
